Award.AwardTitle: Effects of the Cellular Environment of Protein Assembly

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project presents a multiscale computational approach to studying the effects of the environment on protein folding and aggregation. In vivo, proteins fold in a dense environment, rich in interfaces (ranging from membranes to surfaces created by other biomolecules) and with a host of species present that can act as crowding agents. Both crowding and surface effects can dramatically alter protein folding mechanisms as well as affect aggregation pathways. Surfaces play an equally important role in aggregation processes related to biomaterial and biotechnological applications. The PI will use a combination of state of the art fully atomic enhanced sampling molecular dynamics simulations, coupled with novel coarse-grained models that will be developed in the context of this project. The fully atomic simulations will focus on two model systems, the Islet Amyloid Polypeptide and a novel construct of the Tau protein. The folding and early aggregation of these peptides will be studied in the bulk, in the presence of solid model surfaces of different degrees of hydrophobicity (ranging from mica to graphene) and in the presence of the biologically important glycosaminoglycan heparin. Novel coarse-grained models will be developed to probe the effects of crowding and surfaces (including model membrane surfaces) on folding and aggregation. Because coarse-grained models can reach time and lengths scales that far exceed those accessible using fully atomic simulations, they enable the study of the entire aggregation process from monomer folding to full-fledged fibril formation. The proposed integrated multiscale approach aims at elucidating some of the fundamental principles that differentiate in vivo from in vitro folding.

A deeper understanding of the fundamental principles governing protein folding and aggregation will have impacts in a number of disciplines ranging from biotechnology and biomaterials. The research is inherently interdisciplinary, and results from the simulations will be used to guide new experimental studies. All computational models and algorithms developed in the context of this project will be made freely available to the public. The PI is actively involved in the mentoring of under-represented groups in science (both minority and women) and in curricular developments. The PI is involved in chemistry outreach activities to local Santa Barbara elementary school children, including weekly science demonstrations to fifth grade students, as well as monthly "Science Night" events. The PI will expand her outreach to the fifth grade students by introducing new demonstration modules and by expanding the scope of the program to include a significant number of students stemming from primarily Hispanic schools.

This project is jointly supported by the Biomolecular Dynamics, Structure and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research carried out in the context of the NSF grant MCB-115877 focused on the development of computational models to probe how environmental factors influence protein folding and assembly.

Intellectual Merit

The major research activities are summarized below.

Effects of surfaces on protein folding

Protein-surface interactions are ubiquitous in the crowded cytosol, where proteins encounter a variety of surfaces, ranging from membranes surfaces, to the surfaces presented by chaperone molecules. Protein-surface interactions are also at the heart of a number of emerging technologies, including protein micro-arrays, biosensors and biomaterials. We considered the folding of helical and sheet mini-proteins (TrpCage, TrpZip and GB1) on graphene and graphite surfaces with tuned degrees of hydrophobicity, and on hydrophobic and hydrophilic self-assembled monolayers (SAM). An important result from our simulations is that surface hydrophobicity alone cannot be used as a predictor of protein stability on surfaces. Rather, the direct interactions between the protein and the surface dominated over water-mediated interactions, with strong protein-surface interactions leading to protein denaturation on surfaces.

Atomistic and coarse-grained simulations of protein aggregation

We have explored key aspects of protein aggregation, including the initiation of oligomerization through simulations of dimers and other small oligomers, the interaction of inhibitor molecules with oligomers, and we have proposed fibril structures from simulation. We have focused on both model systems (fragments of full length aggregating peptides, such as the YVIFL peptide, the Ab(25-35) peptide, and aggregating fragments of the Tau peptide), as well as full-length aggregating systems (in particular, the Ab(1-40) peptide and the IAPP peptide). Highlights include elucidating the nature of the interactions between IAPP and insulin, characterization of the assembly of Ab peptide fragments into cylindrin structures (a novel oligomer identified in X-ray crystallography), determining how EGCG, Cucurbit[7]uril, 1,2,3,4,6-Penta-O-galloyl-β-d-glucopyranose, and Ab-derived C-terminal fragments can inhibit aggregation, and determining the structure of fibrils of the Fugu-fish variant of the Islet Amyloid Polypeptide (IAPP).

Solvation thermodynamics of amino acids in mixed-osmolyte solutions

We have investigated the solvation thermodynamics of a range of amino acids in urea and TMAO solutions using molecular dynamics simulations and Kirkwood-Buff theory. We found a general amino-acid independent mechanism of mutual exclusion of each of the cosolvents (urea and TMAO) from the amino acid surface. TMAO was seen to dissolve the urea clouds around the amino acids and to increase urea association in the bulk, similarly, TMAO molecules were expelled from the amino acids by urea molecules, thereby reducing the solubility of the amino acids. We also considered the association of a small hydrophobic molecule, neopentane, as a model system for hydrophobic core formation in proteins and showed that a sensitive balance between the TMAO-water and the TMAO-urea interactions governed the osmolyte-induced changes in hydrophobic association in mixed urea-TMAO solutions.

Novel kMC/MD algorithms for protein folding

Sampling conformational space in biomolecular systems poses a challenge because these systems can get trapped in long-lived, metastable states. Enhanced sampling algorithms offer a means to efficiently sample conformational space, however, many of such methods do not readily provide information about the kinetics of these processes. We have developed combined kinetic Monte Carlo/Molecular Dynamics (kMC/MD) algorithms that have enabled us to probe both the thermodynamics and kinetics of folding of small a-helical and b-sheet mini-proteins. The structure of the kMC/MD algorithm is based on a time-scale separation between MD and kMC, with MD sampling the minima on short timescales (ps), while kMC addresses the long-time transitions between minima. A key, novel aspect of our methodology lies in determining transition barriers and rate-constants on the fly based on the instantaneous atomistic configurations obtained from the MD-phase. We developed a number of kMC trial moves, including dihedral rotations, hydrogen-bond moves (H-bond forming and breaking) and backbone displacements. A second development, key to applying the kMC/MD formalism to protein folding, was to implement an extension to Kramer's rate expression via a thermodynamic integration procedure. Most recently, we introduced a new scheme that involved coupling replica exchange molecular dynamics (REMD) with kMC. We applied this method to Dialanine, GB1, TrpZip4 and TrpCage, with a significant speedup compared to REMD alone.

Broader Impacts

The research carried out has ramification on a number of other fields, including biosensors and biomaterials. Educational and outreach activities have included the development of a new computational biochemistry class (with modules drawn from the research performed in this grant), and the development of an outreach program for 5th grade students. 5 postdoctoral students, 3 graduate students, 3 undergraduate students and 3 high school students were involved in the research activities.

Modified by: Joan-Emma Shea
